Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Emergence Of Social Inequality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
How and why social inequality emerges and becomes institutionalized within human societies represent some of the most fundamental issues facing the social sciences. The ramifications of these choices and changes reverberate through modern human societies and have tangible impacts on the lives of modern people. Archaeology is uniquely well suited to examine these issues and to tease out the process(es) by which egalitarian human groups made their first steps towards distributing power and resource access unequally among the members of a given society. It is in this broad vein that the present work will examine the Andean Middle Horizon (AD 500-1000) societies of the San Pedro de Atacama oases (northern Chile), a time and a place in which institutionalized social inequality was just beginning to emerge from a long-standing foundation of egalitarianism. To reconstruct the complex aspects of social inequality, the researchers will focus on detailed analyses of a vast sample of human burials and skeletal remains, revealing both how emerging inequality affected the lives of different individuals in these societies and proposing why these drastic social changes were being made. In the process, undergraduate and graduate students from the investigators' institutions, and in particular Latin American and Hispanic students, will be encouraged to participate and thereby gain invaluable training in archaeological and bio-anthropological research methods.

While archaeologists have examined the processes driving the emergence of social inequality, most studies have viewed the phenomenon of its emergence on the level of whole societies rather than evaluating its effects on the lived experience of individuals and communities. It is in this context that the present work will provide invaluable data: this project will focus on the skeletal remains of various individuals and the manner of their burial for evidence of how and why inequality manifested in each of their lives. To do so, this project will explore the effects of the emergence of differences in social status as it is crystallized in individual experience through a combined research methodology that includes: 1) the study of skeletal remains for evidence of diet, bodily stress, disease, activity patterns, and violence; 2) the evidence of social inequality as expressed by how, and with what each individual was buried; 3) an expansive program of carbon dating that will allow for detailed reconstruction of cemetery use; and 4) a focused analysis of diet through biochemical analysis (stable isotopes). This methodology in combination with the unique archaeological record of the Atacama oases will permit the researchers to address chicken-and-egg debates about whether specific physical manifestations of unequal treatment (dietary difference, greater rates of bodily injury) preceded or postdated other manifestations of burgeoning inequality (e.g. the appearance of exotic goods, the building of elite houses, etc.). Such findings will contribute to a much broader discussion about the profoundly unequal distribution of wealth in contemporary societies and its impact on individual lives, by adding historical depth to our understanding of these processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Collaborative Research: The Emergence of Inequality in the Atacama Oases 

NSF BCS-1359644 (PI C Torres-Rouff, Co-PI M Hubbe) and BCS-1358753 (PI WJ Pestle)

November 25, 2018

 

The Andean Middle Horizon (AD 500-1000) in the Atacama oases of northern Chile traditionally has been described as a period of unparalleled prosperity, peace, and interaction, brought about by the inclusion of the local societies within the sphere of influence of the Tiwanaku state, an expansive polity with its capital near Lake Titicaca, in modern-day Bolivia. However, this understanding of the Middle Horizon as a period of prosperity may mask a deeper level of social inequality within and among the different Atacama oases. Indeed, inequality of some sort is inherent in all human societies, but particularly in those instance where leaders are acquiring power. To explore the emergence of social inequality in Atacama and its ties to Tiwanaku influence, our completed research has attempted to reconstruct different aspects of local life experience through a chronologically controlled analysis of a large set (over 600 individuals) of incredibly well preserved and well documented human skeletons from San Pedro de Atacama, northern Chile. The chronological control is of extreme importance in this case, as the Middle Horizon itself spans several centuries, and our rigorously dating protocol allows us to understand shifts in social inequality and differentiation throughout the period. Broadly speaking, our work has shown that while there were clear tangible benefits of a close tie to the Tiwanaku state for some local residents, the distribution of those benefits, and indeed some of the marked costs for individual well-being, varied greatly between and among members of the local societies. 

 

One of the novel aspects of our research was its multi-disciplinarity. Our skeletal sample was drawn from seven different sites from four oases in San Pedro de Atacama. All told, we analyzed a total of 606 skeletal individuals and their burials, looking for evidence that could speak to patterns of diet, violence, nutritional status and body use. From this larger samples, 197 were sampled for chemical analysis to reconstruct the composition of their diet, and 134 for radiocarbon dating, to reconstruct a refined chronology for the cemeteries studied. Through our work, we aimed: 1) to describe all burial contexts, including tomb structure and contents as well as the distribution of socially valued burial goods; 2) to explore temporal shifts in inequality evidenced in human remains and burial contexts through a rigorous program of carbon dating; 3) to detail dietary variation among individuals through analysis of the bones and their chemical makeup; and 4) to determine differences in body use among individuals by means of activity patterns and traumatic injury analyses. While each of these kinds of data can contribute to our understanding of local life in the past and address questions about inequality, together they provide incredibly detailed insights into individual experiences as inequality emerged. 

 

A number of important points have become visible as we have begun to consolidate these varied data sets. Most notably, and in line with our guiding assumptions, there is no support for a homogeneous life experience among individuals buried in the cemeteries we studied. We observed a very high diversity of practices, diet, susceptibility to violent injury and nutritional status within and between cemeteries. Interestingly, despite significant differences in material culture distribution between the sexes, and some evidence of sex differences in dental health, we did not find any evidence of difference in the overall composition of the diets of men and women. The lack of a clear pattern of association between the life experienced by individuals based on associations with Tiwanaku, gender roles, or even the chronology of the skeletons, leads us to argue that perhaps the increased social complexity of the Middle Horizon is governed by high degrees of local autotomy and variation. Ultimately, our results demonstrate that the development of the Atacama societies was not strongly tied to the Tiwanaku presence, but rather that the ties to Tiwanaku were used during the Middle Horizon to reinforce the emergent inequality that arose as the local communities grew and organized themselves during this period. Based on these results, our future research will focus on building more comparisons between sites to add nuance to these broad interpretations for the oases writ large.
